Your thesis that the vulture capitalism practiced by Multiple Choice Mitt Romney and others was somehow necessary for our economy is unfounded.

First, the countries that started challenging us economically were primarily Western European and Japan. These nations all have stronger labor unions, higher tax rates, and stricter regulations, not the type of vulture capitalism that conservatives like to cheerlead for.

Second, vulture capitalism did nothing to stop the evisceration of stable middle class jobs that provided good wages and benefits, and job security. Instead, it accelerated the disappearance of such jobs.

Third, economic growth may have continued under vulture capitalism, but it changed in a fundamental way. In particular, the benefits of the economic growth over the past 30 years flowed almost entirely to the wealthiest elite in our society, rather than to the nation as a whole.

In short, vulture capitalism was neither necessary nor helpful. What is necessary is repairing the damage and restoring a stable middle class.

Originally one of the functions/tenets of Capitalism was to "act to support multiple stakeholders (shareholders, employees, community) and the environment" - along with the necessary profit function as well, which was needed to support shareholders, EMPLOYEES of all types, and community.

The profit function has now become dominant - excluding certain employees/workers - and this is especially reflected in the current method of profit making by way of the outsourcing of services and manufacturing processes. These vital process must be returned to the USA for the benefit of ALL employees/workers and by extension the community as a whole as well. The preservation of the Middle Class depends on the reversal of outsourcing.

A viable society cannot survive without a middle class. High income inequality leads to distorted markets, robs the citizenry of the opportunity for advancement, promotes poor economic growth, and increases poverty.

For economic growth to take place money must circulate and must be in as many hands as possible. Money must be spent for goods and services on a broad basis and not squirreled away in financial accounts, lands, dwellings, possessions of the few in a country of 308,000,000 people.

Capitalism in its current form robs the society of the where-with-all to survive and thus damages the viability of a well-functioning society with its "multiple stakeholders".

Immediate solution - the taxation of the difference in labor costs from outsourcing.

There are numerous models of capitalism, including Adam Smith's 'invisible hand', which extolls the virtues of competition between small producers; the capitalism practiced by Bain, which regards the maximization of owner/shareholder value as the sole benchmark of business conduct; and the paradigm of corporate social responsibility, which recommends that companies simultaneously make a profit and act to support multiple stakeholders (shareholders, employees, community) and the environment.

It is by no means clear that the Romney/Bain paradigm (maximization of owner/shareholder value) is the best model for companies. Abby Joseph Cohen, who heads investment research at Goldman Sachs, has published data that suggests that companies that seek to maximize profits while maintaining a focus on sustaining multiple stakeholders and enhancing the environment, generate better returns than do companies which focus exclusively on the bottom line, as did Bain Capital under Mitt Romney.

I fear that Romney, in touting the owner value maximization paradigm of capitalism, is backing an outdated model.

"As old Abe said, you can't fool all of the people all of the time." Well, that's true. But the Republicans are depending upon fooling some of the people (50 %) all of the time...and they have done it over and over.

The key is for the MSM to stand up and say "That is a lie" instead of some milquetoast observation that a statement might be misleading.

Hence "class reality." What the sentence means (to my mind) is that reality has nothing to do with the fantasy of class warfare drummed up by the right. Reality is going to win this time because there is no more middle class to fool into thinking they'll be rich one day. And because there's only so much you can blame on the poor before you realize that you're blaming everyone because everyone's poor. Class reality has NOTHING to do with class warfare.

"Class reality has nothing to do with class warfare."

That doesn't make any sense. Class warfare, or the lack thereof, is based on class reality. If there is a reasonable degree of parity between the classes, there is no "warfare." If not, struggle ensues.

No less an authority on being wealthy than Warren Buffet has said that class warfare is a reality in this country, and his (wealthy) class is winning. Or, as an Occupy protest sign said, "The only call it class warfare when we (the 99%) fight back."

The super wealthy, and the Republican party that procures for them, have gone too far, and the inevitable reaction is building. Their propaganda machine has thus far managed to divide the 99%, but it won't for long. As old Abe said, you can't fool all of the people all of the time.
